grammarPoints.meaning: there's no lack of/have plenty of
grammarPoints.usage: Use '不乏' to indicate abundance (literary)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Among them there's no lack of excellent talent

grammarPoints.meaning: can be regarded as/may well be
grammarPoints.usage: Use '不失为' for qualified approval
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Can be regarded as a good method

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无不' for universal application (literary)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Everyone without exception was moved

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无非是' to explain real intention
grammarPoints.example: 他这样做无非是想帮忙
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: His doing this is nothing but wanting to help

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无疑' for certainty
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is undoubtedly correct

grammarPoints.usage: Use '毋庸置疑' for absolute certainty (formal)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: His ability is beyond doubt

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不容置疑' similar to '毋庸置疑'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The facts are indisputable

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无可置疑' for unquestionable truth
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This point is unquestionable

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无可否认' for undeniable facts
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Undeniably, he is excellent

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不可否认' similar to '无可否认'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Undeniable fact

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不言而喻' for obvious truths
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This principle is self-evident

grammarPoints.usage: Use '显而易见' for clear facts
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The answer is obvious

grammarPoints.usage: Use '一目了然' for immediately clear things
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The situation is clear at a glance

grammarPoints.meaning: know like the back of one's hand
grammarPoints.usage: Use '了如指掌' for thorough knowledge
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He knows this like the back of his hand

grammarPoints.usage: Use '了然于胸' for confident understanding
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Have a clear understanding of the situation

grammarPoints.usage: Use '胸有成竹' for confidence in plan
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He has a well-thought-out plan

grammarPoints.meaning: know what one is doing/have a clear idea
grammarPoints.usage: Use '心中有数' for awareness of situation
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I have a clear idea

grammarPoints.usage: Use '心知肚明' for unspoken knowledge
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Everyone knows perfectly well

grammarPoints.usage: Use '心照不宣' for mutual understanding
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is a tacit understanding

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不言自明' for obvious truths
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The principle is self-evident

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不解自明' for self-evident matters
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This question is self-explanatory

grammarPoints.usage: Use '一望而知' for immediately apparent things
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The result is known at a glance

grammarPoints.usage: Use '一看便知' similar to '一望而知'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The answer is known at first sight

grammarPoints.meaning: know as soon as one hears
grammarPoints.usage: Use '一听就知道' for recognition by sound
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Know as soon as one hears it's him

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不难看出' to introduce observation
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Not difficult to see his intentions

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不难发现' to point out facts
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Not hard to discover the problems therein

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不难理解' for comprehensible things
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is not difficult to understand

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不难想象' to suggest likely scenarios
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Not hard to imagine the consequences

grammarPoints.usage: Use '可想而知' for predictable outcomes
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The result is obvious

grammarPoints.usage: Use '可见一斑' for partial evidence of whole
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: From this can be glimpsed

grammarPoints.usage: Use '略见一斑' similar to '可见一斑'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: His talent can be glimpsed

grammarPoints.usage: Use '窥见一斑' for partial view (literary)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Catch a glimpse from this

grammarPoints.meaning: from this it can be known/hence
grammarPoints.usage: Use '由此可知' to draw conclusions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: From this its importance can be known

grammarPoints.usage: Use '由此得知' similar to '由此可知'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: From this learn the truth

grammarPoints.usage: Use '足见' to indicate proof
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Sufficient to show his sincerity

grammarPoints.usage: Use '足以证明' for adequate proof
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is sufficient to prove he is right

grammarPoints.usage: Use '足以说明' for adequate explanation
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Facts are sufficient to explain everything

grammarPoints.usage: Use '充分说明' for complete demonstration
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This fully demonstrates the problem

grammarPoints.usage: Use '充分证明' for complete proof
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Facts fully prove

grammarPoints.usage: Use '恰恰相反' for complete reversal
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Quite the contrary, he's very smart

grammarPoints.usage: Use '正好相反' similar to '恰恰相反'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The result is exactly the opposite

grammarPoints.usage: Use '截然相反' for stark opposition
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two views are diametrically opposite

grammarPoints.usage: Use '大相径庭' for major differences
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The result is vastly different from expectations

grammarPoints.usage: Use '天壤之别' for extreme difference
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: There's a world of difference between the two

grammarPoints.usage: Use '判若两人' for dramatic change in person
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He's now like two different people

grammarPoints.meaning: as different as heaven and earth
grammarPoints.usage: Use '判若云泥' for extreme difference (literary)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two are as different as heaven and earth

grammarPoints.usage: Use '大同小异' for overall similarity
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two plans are largely similar

grammarPoints.meaning: exactly alike/cut from the same cloth
grammarPoints.usage: Use '如出一辙' for identical patterns
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two matters are exactly alike

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不谋而合' for unexpected agreement
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Our ideas coincided without prior agreement

grammarPoints.meaning: do the same without prior agreement
grammarPoints.usage: Use '不约而同' for spontaneous agreement
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Everyone laughed without prior agreement

grammarPoints.usage: Use '异曲同工' for different methods same outcome
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two methods achieve the same result differently

grammarPoints.usage: Use '殊途同归' similar to '异曲同工'
grammarPoints.example: 虽然方式不同，但殊途同归
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Though methods differ, they lead to the same end

grammarPoints.usage: Use '大势所趋' for unavoidable trends
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is the general trend

grammarPoints.usage: Use '势在必行' for necessary actions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Reform is imperative

grammarPoints.usage: Use '势不可挡' for overwhelming force
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The development momentum is unstoppable

grammarPoints.usage: Use '锐不可当' for fierce momentum (literary)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The offensive is irresistible

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不可阻挡' for inevitable progress
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The tide of history cannot be stopped

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不可逆转' for permanent changes
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This trend is irreversible

grammarPoints.usage: Use '覆水难收' for irreversible situations
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Things have come to this, what's done cannot be undone

grammarPoints.meaning: the die is cast/it's a done deal
grammarPoints.usage: Use '木已成舟' for fait accompli
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The die is cast, can only accept

grammarPoints.usage: Use '生米煮成熟饭' for irreversible actions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: What's done is done

grammarPoints.usage: Use '既成事实' for established facts
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is already an accomplished fact

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无可挽回' for lost situations
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The loss is irretrievable

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无法挽回' similar to '无可挽回'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The situation cannot be retrieved

grammarPoints.meaning: better late than never/mend the fold
grammarPoints.usage: Use '亡羊补牢' for corrective action
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It's not too late to mend the fold now

grammarPoints.usage: Use '为时不晚' for timely action
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It's not too late to act now

grammarPoints.usage: Use '为时已晚' for missed opportunities
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It's too late to regret

grammarPoints.usage: Use '为时尚早' for premature actions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: It's too early to draw conclusions now

grammarPoints.usage: Use '操之过急' for excessive haste
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Don't act with undue haste

grammarPoints.meaning: haste makes waste/more haste less speed
grammarPoints.usage: Use '欲速不达' to warn against rushing
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: In doing things, haste makes waste

grammarPoints.usage: Use '急于求成' for excessive eagerness
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Don't be eager for quick success

grammarPoints.meaning: step by step/proceed in an orderly way
grammarPoints.usage: Use '循序渐进' for methodical progress
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Learning should proceed step by step

grammarPoints.usage: Use '稳扎稳打' for cautious progress
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: In doing things, take steady steps

grammarPoints.usage: Use '脚踏实地' for practical approach
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: One should be down-to-earth

grammarPoints.usage: Use '实事求是' for realistic approach
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: We should seek truth from facts

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不切实际' for unrealistic ideas
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This idea is unrealistic

grammarPoints.usage: Use '好高骛远' for impractical ambitions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Don't aim too high

grammarPoints.meaning: have high standards but low ability
grammarPoints.usage: Use '眼高手低' for unrealistic self-assessment
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He has high standards but low ability

grammarPoints.meaning: within one's power/as much as one can
grammarPoints.usage: Use '力所能及' for realistic capabilities
grammarPoints.example: 我会尽力所能及的帮助
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: I'll help as much as I can

grammarPoints.usage: Use '力所不及' for limitations
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is beyond my power

grammarPoints.usage: Use '量力而行' for realistic planning
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Act according to your ability

grammarPoints.meaning: act according to circumstances/tailor to fit
grammarPoints.usage: Use '量体裁衣' for appropriate adaptation
grammarPoints.example: 要量体裁衣地制定计划
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Tailor the plan to fit circumstances

grammarPoints.usage: Use '因地制宜' for contextual adaptation
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Policies should adapt to local conditions

grammarPoints.usage: Use '因时制宜' for temporal adaptation
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Adjust strategies to adapt to the times

grammarPoints.usage: Use '因人而异' for individual differences
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Effects vary from person to person

grammarPoints.usage: Use '因事而异' for situational variation
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Methods vary according to circumstances

grammarPoints.usage: Use '视情况而定' for conditional decisions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This depends on circumstances

grammarPoints.usage: Use '视具体情况而定' for detailed conditions
grammarPoints.example: 安排要视具体情况而定
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Arrangements depend on specific circumstances

grammarPoints.usage: Use '酌情处理' for flexible handling
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Can handle at one's discretion

grammarPoints.usage: Use '灵活处理' for adaptable approach
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Handle problems flexibly

grammarPoints.usage: Use '从长计议' for careful deliberation
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This matter requires long-term consideration

grammarPoints.usage: Use '从长远来看' for long-term view
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: From a long-term perspective this is right

grammarPoints.usage: Use '就长远而言' similar to '从长远来看'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: In the long run it's important

grammarPoints.meaning: as far as present is concerned/for now
grammarPoints.usage: Use '就眼前来说' for immediate situation
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: For now it's acceptable

grammarPoints.usage: Use '当务之急' for most urgent matter
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is the top priority

grammarPoints.usage: Use '迫在眉睫' for urgent situations
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Danger is imminent

grammarPoints.usage: Use '刻不容缓' for matters requiring immediate action
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This matter brooks no delay

grammarPoints.usage: Use '迫不及待' for eagerness
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He can't wait to try

grammarPoints.usage: Use '急不可待' similar to '迫不及待'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The mood is extremely urgent

grammarPoints.usage: Use '争分夺秒' for time-critical work
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: We must race against time

grammarPoints.usage: Use '分秒必争' similar to '争分夺秒'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Every second counts now

grammarPoints.meaning: time waits for no one/time is pressing
grammarPoints.usage: Use '时不我待' to emphasize urgency (literary)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Time waits for no one, must hurry

grammarPoints.usage: Use '机不可失' for rare opportunities
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Opportunity knocks but once

grammarPoints.usage: Use '千载难逢' for extremely rare chances
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is a once in a lifetime opportunity

grammarPoints.meaning: once in a hundred years/extremely rare
grammarPoints.usage: Use '百年不遇' for very rare events
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Once in a hundred years opportunity

grammarPoints.usage: Use '难能可贵' for admirable qualities
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This spirit is commendable

grammarPoints.usage: Use '难得一见' for rare sights
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This sight is rarely seen

grammarPoints.usage: Use '罕见' for unusual occurrences
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This situation is rare

grammarPoints.meaning: unique/the only one of its kind
grammarPoints.usage: Use '绝无仅有' for unique things
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This phenomenon is unique

grammarPoints.usage: Use '独一无二' for uniqueness
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: His style is unique

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无与伦比' for supreme excellence
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: His talent is incomparable

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无可比拟' similar to '无与伦比'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The beauty is beyond comparison

grammarPoints.usage: Use '无出其右' for being the best (literary)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: None can surpass his skill

grammarPoints.usage: Use '首屈一指' for being number one
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He is second to none in this area

grammarPoints.usage: Use '数一数二' for being in top ranks
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This company is among the best

grammarPoints.usage: Use '名列前茅' for high ranking
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: His grades rank high

grammarPoints.usage: Use '出类拔萃' for excellence
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Her performance is outstanding

grammarPoints.usage: Use '卓越' for exceptional quality
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Outstanding achievements

grammarPoints.usage: Use '卓尔不群' for being outstanding (literary)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: His talent stands out from the crowd

grammarPoints.meaning: stand out like a crane among chickens
grammarPoints.usage: Use '鹤立鸡群' for conspicuous excellence
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He stands out among classmates

grammarPoints.usage: Use '出人头地' for success and distinction
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He finally rose above others

grammarPoints.usage: Use '脱颖而出' for emerging as outstanding
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: She stood out from the crowd

grammarPoints.meaning: take first place/come out on top
grammarPoints.usage: Use '独占鳌头' for winning first place
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He took first place in the competition

grammarPoints.usage: Use '技高一筹' for superior ability
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He is indeed a cut above

grammarPoints.usage: Use '略胜一筹' for slight superiority
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This plan is slightly better

grammarPoints.usage: Use '棋逢对手' for equal opponents
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two are evenly matched

grammarPoints.usage: Use '旗鼓相当' for equal strength
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Both sides are evenly matched in strength

grammarPoints.usage: Use '势均力敌' similar to '旗鼓相当'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two teams are evenly matched

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不相上下' for close competition
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two are about the same in ability

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不分伯仲' for indistinguishable excellence
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two contestants are equally matched

grammarPoints.meaning: hard to tell who is better
grammarPoints.usage: Use '难分高下' for close competition
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Hard to tell which plan is better

grammarPoints.usage: Use '难分难解' for intense competition
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The match is locked in battle

grammarPoints.usage: Use '不分胜负' for draws
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Both sides tied

grammarPoints.usage: Use '平分秋色' for equal achievement
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two are equally matched

grammarPoints.usage: Use '相提并论' for comparison (often negative)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two cannot be mentioned in the same breath

grammarPoints.meaning: speak of in the same terms/compare
grammarPoints.usage: Use '同日而语' similar to '相提并论'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Cannot be spoken of in the same terms

grammarPoints.usage: Use '望其项背' for ability to match (often negative)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Hard to catch up with

grammarPoints.meaning: be left far behind/cannot hope to match
grammarPoints.usage: Use '望尘莫及' for vast inferiority
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: We are left far behind

grammarPoints.usage: Use '相形见绌' for unfavorable comparison
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Pale in comparison

grammarPoints.usage: Use '黯然失色' for being outshone
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Everything else pales by comparison

grammarPoints.meaning: complement each other/bring out the best
grammarPoints.usage: Use '相得益彰' for mutual enhancement
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two complement each other

grammarPoints.usage: Use '相辅相成' for complementarity
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Theory and practice complement each other

grammarPoints.usage: Use '相映成趣' for harmonious contrast
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Mountains and water set each other off beautifully

grammarPoints.usage: Use '相得益彰' for beneficial combination
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two mutually enhance each other

grammarPoints.usage: Use '相互呼应' for coordination
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Front and back echo each other

grammarPoints.meaning: coordinate at a distance/echo from afar
grammarPoints.usage: Use '遥相呼应' for distant coordination
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: North and south coordinate from afar

grammarPoints.usage: Use '前呼后应' for coordinated action
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Actions are well-coordinated

grammarPoints.meaning: coordinate inside and outside/act in concert
grammarPoints.usage: Use '里应外合' for coordinated attack
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The enemy acts in concert inside and outside

grammarPoints.usage: Use '珠联璧合' for perfect pairing (literary)
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The two are a perfect match

grammarPoints.usage: Use '天作之合' for perfect match
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: They are a match made in heaven

grammarPoints.usage: Use '天衣无缝' for perfection without flaw
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The plan is flawless

grammarPoints.usage: Use '浑然天成' for natural perfection
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: The work is naturally perfect

grammarPoints.usage: Use '水到渠成' for natural fruition
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: As long as you work hard, things will fall into place

grammarPoints.meaning: things will happen when conditions are ripe
grammarPoints.usage: Use '瓜熟蒂落' for natural timing
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: No need to rush, things will happen when ripe

grammarPoints.usage: Use '水滴石穿' for power of persistence
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Believe in the power of persistence

grammarPoints.usage: Use '铁杵成针' for achievement through perseverance
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: As long as you persist, perseverance pays off

grammarPoints.usage: Use '功到自然成' for natural success through work
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Don't worry, success comes with sustained effort

grammarPoints.pattern: Subject + 一分耕耘一分收获
grammarPoints.usage: Use '一分耕耘一分收获' for proportional returns
grammarPoints.example: 记住一分耕耘一分收获
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Remember you reap what you sow

grammarPoints.pattern: Subject + 种瓜得瓜种豆得豆
grammarPoints.usage: Use '种瓜得瓜种豆得豆' for consequences matching actions
grammarPoints.example: 种瓜得瓜种豆得豆，因果循环
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: You reap what you sow, cause and effect

grammarPoints.meaning: reap what one has sown/suffer consequences
grammarPoints.usage: Use '自食其果' for negative consequences
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He is now reaping what he sowed

grammarPoints.usage: Use '自作自受' similar to '自食其果'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is suffering from one's own actions

grammarPoints.usage: Use '咎由自取' for self-inflicted problems
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This trouble was brought on oneself

grammarPoints.meaning: be caught in one's own trap
grammarPoints.usage: Use '作茧自缚' for self-imposed restrictions
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He is caught in his own trap

grammarPoints.pattern: Subject + 搬起石头砸自己的脚
grammarPoints.usage: Use '搬起石头砸自己的脚' for self-defeating actions
grammarPoints.example: 这是搬起石头砸自己的脚
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is shooting oneself in the foot

grammarPoints.usage: Use '得不偿失' for net loss
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Doing this, the loss outweighs the gain

grammarPoints.meaning: lose big by being penny wise
grammarPoints.usage: Use '因小失大' for prioritizing wrong things
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Don't lose big by being penny wise

grammarPoints.meaning: attend to trifles and neglect essentials
grammarPoints.usage: Use '舍本逐末' for wrong priorities
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is neglecting essentials for trifles

grammarPoints.meaning: put the cart before the horse
grammarPoints.usage: Use '本末倒置' for reversed priorities
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Doing this is putting the cart before the horse

grammarPoints.usage: Use '轻重倒置' for confused priorities
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Cannot confuse priorities

grammarPoints.meaning: fail to distinguish primary from secondary
grammarPoints.usage: Use '主次不分' for inability to prioritize
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: In doing things cannot fail to distinguish priorities

grammarPoints.usage: Use '分清主次' for proper prioritization
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Must distinguish primary from secondary

grammarPoints.usage: Use '轻重缓急' for priority ranking
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Must distinguish order of importance and urgency

grammarPoints.usage: Use '孰轻孰重' to question priorities
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Must understand which is more important

grammarPoints.meaning: which is right and which is wrong
grammarPoints.usage: Use '孰是孰非' for moral judgment
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Must distinguish right from wrong

grammarPoints.meaning: have a clear sense of right and wrong
grammarPoints.usage: Use '是非分明' for moral clarity
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: One should have a clear sense of right and wrong

grammarPoints.usage: Use '是非不分' for moral confusion
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He cannot distinguish right from wrong

grammarPoints.meaning: confuse right and wrong/reverse black and white
grammarPoints.usage: Use '黑白颠倒' for distorting truth
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Cannot confuse right and wrong

grammarPoints.usage: Use '颠倒是非' similar to '黑白颠倒'
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He is confounding right and wrong

grammarPoints.usage: Use '混淆是非' for deliberately confusing truth
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Don't confuse right and wrong

grammarPoints.usage: Use '混淆视听' for spreading confusion
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: He is confusing the public

grammarPoints.meaning: call a deer a horse/deliberate misrepresentation
grammarPoints.usage: Use '指鹿为马' for blatant distortion
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: This is deliberate misrepresentation

grammarPoints.usage: Use '颠倒黑白' for distorting facts
grammarPoints.exampleTranslation: Cannot reverse black and white
